sections.title: Sundays
office_timing: Sunday's Office begins on Saturday at I Vespers and ends with Compline on Sunday
precedence: A I class Sunday takes precedence of any feast whatever occurring that day; exception: if December 8 falls on Sunday, the feast of the Immaculate Conception is kept in place of the Sunday.
A II class Sunday takes precedence of a II class feast occurring the same day.
special_cases: A feast of Our Lord of the I class (e.g., Precious Blood, July 1) or of the II class (e.g., Transfiguration, Aug. 6) coinciding with a II class Sunday takes the place of the Sunday with all rights and privileges; no commemoration of the Sunday.
A II class Sunday takes precedence of the Commemoration of All the Faithful Departed (All Souls).
concurrence_rules: If I or II Vespers of a I or II class Sunday concur with Vespers of a I or II class feast, the II Vespers of the concurrent Office of the same degree has precedence; the other Office is only commemorated.
If Dec. 8 falls on Saturday: Vespers are of the feast with commemoration of Sunday.
If Dec. 8 falls on Monday: Vespers on Dec. 7 are of Sunday with commemoration of the feast.
If the Transfiguration (II class) falls on Saturday: Vespers that day are of the feast, without commemoration of the (II class) Sunday.

perpetual_sunday_exceptions.note: The Sunday Office excludes any feast that would be kept perpetually on Sunday, except the following which replace the Sunday (no commemoration of the Sunday):
feasts: Holy Name of Jesus (Sunday between Jan. 2–5; if no Sunday, Jan. 2)
Holy Family, Jesus, Mary and Joseph (I Sunday after the Epiphany)
Christ the King (last Sunday of October)
I class feasts of Our Lord which in diocesan or religious calendars are at present kept on II class Sundays

sections.title: Ferias
sections.definition: Every day of the week except Sunday.
office_timing: The Office of a feria begins with Matins and ends with Compline.
The Office of Saturday (except Holy Saturday) ends with None.

classes.precedence: Takes precedence of any feast whatever, and only allows of a privileged commemoration.

includes: Ember days of Advent, Lent, and September
precedence: Give way to a II class feast of the universal Church and are then only commemorated (e.g., St. Thomas Apostle, Dec. 21; St. Matthew, Sept. 21 if coinciding with Ember day).
A II class feria takes precedence of a II class feast in a diocesan or religious calendar; the latter is only commemorated.

includes: Weekdays of Lent or Passiontide (from Ash Wednesday to Saturday before Palm Sunday inclusive) not mentioned above
Ferias of Advent to Dec. 16 inclusive not mentioned above
celebration_rules: Lenten/Passiontide ferias of III class do not allow celebration of III class feasts.
Advent ferias of III class allow the celebration of III class feasts.
classes.commemoration: If these ferias cannot be kept, they are commemorated.

includes: All other ferias not included above
classes.commemoration: If they cannot be kept, they are not commemorated.

sections.title: Vigils
sections.definition: Liturgical day preceding a feast and preparatory to it. The vigil of Easter, however, is not a liturgical day and is kept in a special way.

notes: If Dec. 24 falls on Sunday, Office and Mass are of the vigil, without commemoration of the Sunday.
Take precedence of all feasts and allow of no commemoration.

includes: Vigil of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist
Vigil of SS. Peter and Paul
classes.precedence: Take precedence of liturgical days of I or II class.
classes.if_not_kept: If they cannot be kept, they are commemorated according to the rubrics.

classes.precedence: Takes precedence of liturgical days of the IV class; if it cannot be kept, it is commemorated.

omission_rules: Vigils of the II and III class are simply omitted on any Sunday and on a I class feast.
They are also omitted if the feast they would precede is transferred to another day or reduced to a simple commemoration.
office_timing: The Office of a vigil begins with Matins and ends when the Office of the following day begins.

sections.title: Feasts
sections.definition: A feast means a liturgical day when the Church's public worship honours a mystery of Our Lord, or venerates Our Lady, the Angels, Saints, or Blessed.

notes: Office begins with I Vespers on the previous day.
Office normally extends from Matins to Compline of the same day.
classes.special_case: II class feasts of Our Lord have I Vespers whenever they are kept on a Sunday which they displace.

sections.title: Octaves
sections.definition: An octave is the celebration of a greater feast continued for eight consecutive days.

classes.rule: All days within these octaves are I class.
Days within the octave are II class; the octave-day (Jan. 1) is I class.

special_rules_christmas_octave: Dec. 27: St. John the Evangelist (II class)
Dec. 29: Commemoration of St. Thomas, Bp. and Martyr
Dec. 31: Commemoration of St. Silvester, Pope and Conf.
Feasts not in universal calendar can only be kept if I class and in honour of saints already celebrated; others transferred after octave.
sections.sunday_in_octave_rule: Office of the Sunday in the octave of Christmas is said with commemoration of any feast, unless it coincides with a I class feast (then feast takes precedence with commemoration of Sunday).

seasons.name: Advent
seasons.start: I Vespers of I Sunday of Advent

seasons.name: Lent (tempus quadragesimale)
seasons.end: Mass of the Easter Vigil exclusive

subperiods.name: Lent
subperiods.end: None of Saturday before Passion Sunday

subperiods.name: Holy Week
subperiods.notes: Last three days are the Triduum sacrum

seasons.name: Paschal Time (tempus paschale)
seasons.end: None of Saturday after Whit Sunday

subperiods.name: Easter
subperiods.end: None of Wednesday vigil of Ascension

subperiods.name: Ascension
subperiods.end: None of Saturday vigil of Whit Sunday

seasons.name: Per annum
seasons.ends_again: None of Saturday before I Sunday of Advent

greater.transfer_rule: If Easter Sunday or Monday, transferred to Tuesday.
greater.procession: Procession with Litany of the Saints (petitions not doubled) and prayers, or special prayers appointed by Ordinary if no procession possible.
greater.rogation_mass: Sung immediately after procession or special prayers, even if prayers are said in the evening.

lesser.transfer_rule: Ordinary may transfer to other three days as convenient for region.
lesser.celebration: No Office celebration, only Mass following procession or prayers.
lesser.rules: Follow same rule as Greater Litanies for processions, prayers, and Mass/commemoration.

sections.title: Commemorations
sections.definition: Apply to both Mass and Office, in cases of occurrence or concurrence.

inseparable.description: In Office and Mass of St. Peter there is always a commemoration of St. Paul and vice versa; counted as one prayer.
rules: Office of St. Peter/Paul: prayer of one Apostle followed by other under single conclusion, no antiphon/versicle.
Mass of St. Peter/Paul: prayer of other Apostle added under single conclusion.
Whenever one Apostle is commemorated, the other is added at once before any other commemorations.

limits: I class days & non-conventual sung Masses: only one privileged commemoration.
II class Sundays: only one commemoration allowed (of a II class feast), omitted if privileged commemoration required.
Other II class days: only one commemoration allowed (privileged or ordinary).
III/IV class days: only two commemorations allowed.
exclusion_rules: Office/Mass/commemoration of any feast/mystery of one divine Person excludes that of another of same Person.
Office/Mass/commemoration of a Sunday excludes that of a feast/mystery of Our Lord, and vice versa.
Office/Mass/commemoration of a season excludes another of the season.
Office/Mass/commemoration of BVM or any Saint excludes another of same BVM/Saint, except where named in Sunday/feria prayer.
sections.ordering: Seasonal commemoration comes first; others follow the decree's table of precedence.
sections.overflow_rule: Any commemoration exceeding the number allowed must be omitted.

title: Rubrics for the Office
source_notes: Structured from user-provided text (Liber Usualis changes, 1960 rubrics), section II a–e.

subsections.title: General Rules

notes: Compline is often treated separately in the rubrics.

forms_of_recitation.definition: By a community bound by law to the Office in choir.
By a community not bound to choir.

subsections.applicability_rule: Unless otherwise expressly noted, the following rules apply to Office in choir, in common (even if only 2–3 persons), and to private recitation.

subsections.title: Time When the Canonical Hours Should Be Said
subsections.principle: The Hours sanctify the times of the natural day; it is praiseworthy to recite them as near their true time as possible.

Matins.norm: May be said after midday of the preceding day, but not before 2:00 PM.

Lauds.norm: Morning prayer; said in the morning in choir or in common; commendable likewise in private.

Vespers.norm: Said after midday (also in Lent and Passiontide).

Compline.norm: Fittingly said as final night-prayers, even if for good reason Matins of the following day has already been said.
night_form: Omit the Pater noster after the versicle 'Adjutorium nostrum'.
In choir or common: spend a reasonable time in examination of conscience; then say the Confiteor and continue as usual.
The same practice is commendable in private recitation.

subsections.title: Arrangement of the Divine Office
subsections.vespers_acquisition: Feasts which have no I Vespers and acquire them under the new rubrics borrow everything from II Vespers, except items explicitly proper to I Vespers.

endings.Matins_if_Lauds_do_not_follow_immediatel: ℣. Fidelium animae (prayer for the faithful departed).
endings.Lauds_Terce_Sext_None_Vespers: ℣. Fidelium animae (prayer for the faithful departed).

daily_conclusion.norm: After Compline: Antiphon of Our Lady with versicle and prayer, then 'Divinum auxilium'; except on the last three days of Holy Week and in the Office of the Dead.
daily_conclusion.indulgence_note: The remission of faults and attached indulgences of 'Sacrosanctae' are connected to this final Antiphon of Our Lady.

hymns.general_rule: Hymns are said at each Hour as provided.
omissions: From Matins of Maundy Thursday until None of the Saturday in Easter Week.
In the Office of the Dead.
hymns.lesser_hours_and_compline: Assigned hymns are always said, except at Terce on Whit Sunday and during its Octave.
hymns.non_transferability: Proper hymns assigned to certain Hours are never transferred to another Hour.

conclusions_doxology.default: Unless stated otherwise in these rubrics, each hymn uses the usual conclusion as in the Liber Usualis, without seasonal/feast substitutions.
conclusions_doxology.commemoration_note: A commemoration never introduces a proper doxology to the hymns of the Office of the day.

antiphons.use: Said before and after psalms and canticles at all Hours (number varies by Hour/Office).
omitted_at: Lesser Hours and Compline on the last three days of Holy Week.
Lesser Hours and Compline on Easter Day and during its Octave.
Lesser Hours and Compline during the Office of the Dead on November 2.
antiphons.integrity: Antiphons are always said entire, before and after, at all Hours.
antiphons.asterisk: The asterisk after the incipit indicates the extent of the intonation.
antiphons.non_transferability: If proper antiphons assigned to certain Hours cannot be said, they are omitted, not transferred.

alleluia_rules.paschal_time: Add 'alleluia' at the end of antiphons if not already present.
alleluia_rules.septuagesima_to_easter_eve: Omit any 'alleluia' at the end of antiphons.

psalms_and_canticles.incipit_overlap: If a psalm/canticle begins with the same words as the antiphon, do not repeat; begin with the next word—provided no 'alleluia' is to be added to the antiphon.
psalms_and_canticles.no_reassignment: A psalm that cannot be said at its proper Hour is not moved to another Hour; it is omitted.

gloria_patri.rule: At the end of psalms and canticles (except Benedicite), say 'Gloria Patri'.
gloria_patri.omitted_on: Last three days of Holy Week.

psalms_and_canticles.office_of_the_dead: In place of 'Gloria Patri' say 'Requiem aeternam'.
psalms_and_canticles.athanasian_creed: Said only on Trinity Sunday, at Prime, after the psalms and before the repetition of the antiphon.

subsections.title: Hymns (additional summary)
subsections.note: Included under c) parts->hymns; this node retains a flat view for quick access.
omitted: Triduum from Maundy Thursday Matins through Easter Saturday None
exceptions: Terce on Whit Sunday and during its Octave

subsections.title: Antiphons, Psalms, and Canticles (additional summary)
subsections.note: Included under c) parts->antiphons and parts->psalms_and_canticles; this node provides a flat view for indexers.
antiphons_omitted_at: Lesser Hours & Compline on the last three days of Holy Week
Lesser Hours & Compline on Easter Day and during its Octave
Lesser Hours & Compline on Nov. 2 (Office of the Dead)

gloria_patri.omit_on: Last three days of Holy Week

Mass_in_cantu.definition: Celebrant actually sings parts reserved to him by the rubrics.
subtypes: Missa cantata — sung without sacred ministers.

definitions.Said_Mass: Missa lecta; celebrant does not sing.
definitions.Pontifical_Mass: High Mass celebrated by a Bishop (or other with right) with pontifical ceremonies.

participation.principle: Those present should take part, each in his proper way.
participation.reference: Instruction on sacred music and the liturgy, S.R.C., 3 Sept 1958

subsections.title: Conventual Mass
rules: For a serious reason the Superior may appoint Sext or None instead.
On Whitsun (Pentecost) Eve, conventual Mass follows None.

parts.title: Psalm 'Judica me, Deus', Confiteor, and Censing of the Altar
parts.norm: Said at the foot of the altar at every Mass (sung or said).
omit_entire_block_when_mass_follows_rite: Purification of Our Lady — after blessing of candles and procession
Ash Wednesday — after blessing and imposition of ashes
Palm Sunday — after blessing of palms and procession
Rogation Mass — after Greater or Lesser Litanies procession
Masses following certain consecrations per the Roman Pontifical
omit_psalm_only_additionally_in: Seasonal Masses from the I Sunday of the Passion through the Evening Mass of Maundy Thursday
parts.censing: Censings obligatory at high Mass; permitted at all sung Masses.

parts.title: Prayers (Collects) at Sung Mass
parts.general_limit: After the Collect of the day: constraints on additional prayers apply; never more than three total.

sung_mass_non_conventual.allow: Only a single privileged commemoration under a single conclusion with the Collect.
sung_mass_non_conventual.applies_also_to: Conventual Mass on I-class days and I-class votive Masses.

class_based_rules: II-class Sundays: only the commemoration of a II-class feast; omit if a privileged commemoration is required.
Other II-class days and II-class votive Masses: allow one commemoration (privileged OR ordinary).
III- or IV-class days or votive Masses: allow only two additional prayers total.
parts.flectamus_genua: Whenever 'Flectamus genua / Levate' appears, at high Mass the deacon says it; at other Masses, the celebrant. All kneel briefly, then rise at 'Levate' for the prayer.
parts.missions_sunday: On the penultimate Sunday of October (or Sunday appointed by the Bishop) add the Prayer for the Propagation of the Faith under a single conclusion.

parts.title: Lessons at Mass

ember_saturdays.conventual_or_ordination_mass: All lessons with versicles and prayers must be read.
ember_saturdays.other_masses: Say only the first prayer (with Flectamus genua if prescribed), the first lesson with its gradual/alleluia; then Dominus vobiscum, Oremus, the second prayer (no Flectamus genua), and any commemorations. Omit the remaining intermediate lessons with their versicles/prayers; proceed directly to the last lesson or Epistle (and on Whit Saturday, the Sequence).

parts.saturday_ordination_choice: On Ember Saturday and the Saturday 'Sitientes', the Mass for conferring Holy Orders should be that of the Saturday, even if a I or II class feast is otherwise kept.
parts.celebrant_omits_chanted_texts: At sung Mass, anything proper to deacon, subdeacon, or lector, as part of their office, is not duplicated by the celebrant.
parts.sermon: After the Gospel, especially on Sundays and days of obligation, a short sermon should be preached if opportune. If preached by a priest other than the celebrant, it must not interrupt the celebrant's parts; the Mass is paused and then resumed.

parts.title: The Creed (Symbolum)
said_on: Every Sunday (even if the Office is replaced or a II-class votive Mass is used)
I-class feasts and I-class votive Masses
II-class feasts of Our Lord and of Our Lady
During the Octaves of Christmas, Easter, and Whit Sunday (even with an occurring feast or a votive Mass)
Dies natalis of Apostles and Evangelists; feasts of St. Peter’s Chair and St. Barnabas
not_said_on: Other II-class feasts (except those listed under 'said_on')
III- or IV-class festive or votive Masses
Because of any mere commemoration at Mass

parts.title: Offertory and Communion Antiphons
parts.alleluia_rule: If the printed antiphon itself concludes with 'alleluia', it is sung year-round except from Septuagesima through Holy Saturday. Example: Offertory 'Beata es, Virgo Maria' retains its alleluia outside that pre-Paschal period.

parts.title: Holy Communion of the Faithful
parts.proper_time: Immediately after the celebrant’s Communion at Mass.
parts.minister: Ordinarily by the celebrant himself; other priests may assist when numbers are large.
parts.unfitting: Another priest giving Communion at the same altar during Mass but not at the proper time.
parts.outside_mass: May be given immediately before/after Mass or apart from Mass using the Roman Ritual form.
parts.formula_at_mass: When Communion is given during Mass: after consuming the Precious Blood, and without a Confiteor or absolution, the celebrant says 'Ecce Agnus Dei' and thrice 'Domine, non sum dignus', then distributes Communion.

parts.title: Conclusion of Mass

dismissal.ordinary: Ite, missa est — response: Deo gratias.
dismissal.kyriale_note: In Kyriale Masses XVI, XVII, XVIII the Ite, missa est is taken from Mass XV; this is permitted also wherever the Ite is sung without alleluia.

exceptions.case: Evening Mass of Maundy Thursday (followed by solemn deposition) and Masses followed by a procession (e.g., Corpus Christi)
exceptions.formula: Benedicamus Domino — response: Deo gratias — melodies per Mass II or XVI only.
Ite, missa est with a double 'alleluia' appended.

parts.blessing: After 'Placeat', the blessing is given; omitted only when Benedicamus Domino or Requiescant in pace is used.

last_gospel.ordinary: The Prologue of St. John (In principio) at every Mass.
last_gospel.palm_sunday_note: At Masses NOT preceded by the blessing of palms and procession, say the proper last Gospel of the day instead.
omitted_entirely_when: Palm Sunday Mass following the blessing of palms and procession
Masses of the Dead followed by Absolution at the catafalque
Masses following certain consecrations per the Roman Pontifical

version: 1960 Rubricae Breviarii et Missalis Romani — integrated summary

notes: Mass is public worship offered in the name of Christ and the Church; avoid the term 'private Mass'.
Mass should ordinarily conform to the Office of the day; exceptions: votive Masses and Masses of the Dead.
Two kinds of Masses: in cantu (sung) and said (Missa lecta).
High (solemn) Mass: sung with sacred ministers; Missa cantata: sung without sacred ministers.
Pontifical Mass: high Mass by a Bishop (or entitled prelate) with pontifical ceremonies.
Active participation of the faithful is encouraged per S.R.C. Instruction on sacred music and liturgy (3 Sept 1958).

metadata.merge_strategy: deep_merge(dicts recursively; lists deduped with stable order; scalar conflicts prefer longer string or right-hand side)
